title: 113_hr1905
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Mother's Day Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that Anna Jarvis, born in West Virginia in 1864, founded modern Mother's Day to honor her mother. In 1914, the second Sunday in May was designated as Mother's Day by the Sixty-Third Congress. The Congress designated the second Sunday in May as Mother's Day in Res. 263, encouraging Americans to display the American flag at their homes as a tribute to mothers. President Woodrow Wilson also issued a proclamation in 1914 for government officials to display the flag on all buildings and for the public to do the same on Mother's Day. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury shall mint and issue $1 coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The coins minted under this Act shall commemorate the 100th anniversary of Mother's Day with specific design requirements and inscriptions. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2014, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority terminates on December 31, 2014. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount as well. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

Sales of coins minted under this Act require a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharge proceeds will be split equally between St. Jude Children's Research Hospital and the National Osteoporosis Foundation for research purposes. Both organizations will be audited for the funds received.
